Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php

The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Nine firms agreed to pay a total of $355,000 in civil penalties to settle allegations that they knowingly failed to report to the CPSC immediately, as required by federal law, that their children's hooded sweatshirts, jackets, or sweaters were sold with drawstrings at the hood and neck and thus posed a strangulation hazard.
Info Source: https://www.cpsc.gov/Newsroom/News-Releases/2008/Nine-Firms-Agree-To-Pay-More-Than-350000-in-Civil-Penalties-For-Failing-To-Timely-Report-Drawstrings-In-Childrens-Outerwear

Description: The Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a settlement with Sears Home Improvement Products Inc. that resolved alleged violations of the federal Lead Renovation, Repair and Painting (RRP) Rule for work performed by Sears' contractors during home renovation projects across the country.  Under the settlement, Sears was to implement a comprehensive, corporate-wide program to ensure that the contractors it hires to perform work are properly certified and follow required procedures to prevent exposure to lead dust from home renovation activities.  Sears also agreed to pay a $400,000 civil penalty.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/sears-home-improvement-products-inc-improve-public-health-protections-lead-pollution-during

Description: Amazon.com, Inc.; Leon Max, Inc.; Macy's, Inc.; and Sears, Roebuck and Co. and its Kmart subsidiaries, Kmart Corporation and Kmart.com, agreed to pay penalties totaling $1.26 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they violated the Textile Products Identification Act (Textile Act) and the FTC's Textile Rules by labeling and advertising products sold in stores and online as made of bamboo, while they actually were made of rayon.
Info Source: https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2013/01/four-national-retailers-agree-pay-penalties-totaling-126-million

Description: Settlement of allegations relating to the sale of toy guns that look like real guns.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20161008122521/http://www.ag.ny.gov/press-release/ag-schneiderman-cracks-down-illegal-toy-guns-sales-announces-settlements-amazon

Description: The settlement requires K-Mart to pay $100,000 and implement compliance programs in accordance with the state's Pharmacy Act, which requires pharmacies to pass retail savings from the sale of generic prescription drugs to consumers.
Info Source: https://mailchi.mp/wvago/wva-ag-k-mart-reach-100000-settlement

Description: Kmart agreed to pay $2.55 million to settle multistate allegations that it submitted false claims and false statements to state Medicaid programs relating to partial fills of prescriptions.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20190422171535/https:/law.georgia.gov/press-releases/2013-10-23/attorney-general-olens-announces-settlement-kmart-over-drug-billing

Description: A group of major retailers and a group of jewelry manufacturers joined a settlement involving the presence of lead in costume jewelry sold to children.
Info Source: https://www.oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/attorney-general-lockyer-announces-settlement-major-us-companies-reduce-lead

Description: Kmart Corporation agreed to pay $105,500 to resolve allegations that it failed to provide consumers with required unit prices in its Maryland stores.
Info Source: http://www.marylandattorneygeneral.gov/press/2018/110218b.pdf
https://www.ncdoj.gov/News-and-Alerts/News-Releases-and-Advisories/Attorney-General-Josh-Stein-Announces-Nearly-$1-Mi.aspx

Description: Settlement agreement resolving allegations of violating the Kansas No-Call Act.

Description: The New York State Attorney announced an agreement with Sears Roebuck Company under which the retailing giant will change its policy of requiring repair technicians to work on Saturdays even if their religion prohibited it.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20101116032921/http://www.ag.ny.gov/media_center/2000/apr/apr04b_00.html

Description: Sears, Roebuck & Co. agreed to pay $200,000 in settlement of allegations the company defrauded Spanish-speaking consumers through sales of maintenance service agreements. The State had alleged that Spanish-speaking customers were given details of the service contracts verbally in Spanish, but that the contracts they were given to sign were in English.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20030304034428/http://www.attorney_general.state.az.us/press_releases/oct/102102a.html
https://www.oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/attorney-general-district-attorneys-settle-consumer-protection-complaint-against

Description: Sears, Roebuck and Co. and Kmart agreed to pay a total of $1.1 million in settlement of allegations by six California District Attorneys that they charged more for California Redemption Value beverage containers than allowed by law, and that Kmart charged the fee for containers it did not apply to.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20110309095818/http://da.co.la.ca.us/mr/071910a.htm

Description: Kmart agreed to pay $8.65 million to the California Attorney General and the District Attorneys of Riverside, San Joaquin and Ventura counties to resolve allegations relating to the mishandling of hazardous wastes.
Info Source: https://oag.ca.gov/news/press-releases/brown-and-district-attorneys-sue-target-illegal-disposal-hazardous-waste

Description: Sears, Roebuck and Co. agreed to pay $450,000 in settlement of allegations of sales tax errors and overselling of oil and repairs in its Sears Automotive Repair Dealerships.
Info Source: https://www.co.fresno.ca.us/Home/ShowDocument?id=10410

Description: Sears agreed to pay $235,000 in civil penalties and was barred from selling misbranded or falsely advertised supplements under a settlement reached with the Orange County District Attorney's Office.
Info Source: https://www.ocregister.com/2016/12/30/ocda-settles-lawsuit-alleging-retail-giant-sears-sold-fda-banned-nutritional-supplements/
